issues.description: The problem statement (and the solution) expects a Stock method named emptyStock(): void, but the template implementation provides a method named clearInventory() instead. This is a structural signature/name mismatch: students following the specification will look for/implement emptyStock(), but the starter code only exposes clearInventory(), leading to confusion or compilation problems when referencing the method.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across artifacts. Preferred fixes: (a) Rename the template method clearInventory() to emptyStock(), matching the problem statement and solution; or (b) add a public emptyStock() method in the template that delegates to clearInventory(), so both names work. Update any references so all three artifacts use the same method name.

issues.description: The problem statement's UML and the solution use the method name emptyStock() on the Stock class (to clear the inventory), but the template code provides a method named clearInventory() instead. This naming mismatch for the same conceptual operation (emptying/clearing the stock) can confuse students: the problem description/test expectations reference emptyStock(), while the starter code exposes clearInventory(), forcing students to reconcile two different names for the same entity.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name across artifacts. Rename the template's clearInventory() to emptyStock(), or add an emptyStock() wrapper that calls clearInventory(), so the method name matches the problem statement and solution. Ensure tests and documentation consistently refer to emptyStock().
